channel.title: Grant Ingraham — Author: AI & Cybersecurity
channel.description: Helping everyday people use modern technology safely, confidently, and without fear.

wp:category.wp:category_description: Clear, plain-English introductions to artificial intelligence and how it appears in daily life—smartphones, search, shopping, and home technology. Designed for beginners, families, and seniors.
Long-form articles and essays by Grant Ingraham on AI, cybersecurity, and everyday digital safety. These deep-dive pieces explore how modern technology affects families, seniors, and everyday users.
Practical cybersecurity guidance for everyday users. Learn how to protect passwords, secure devices, enable 2FA, avoid scams, and stay safe online with clear, plain-English advice.
Tips and explanations that help you recognize and avoid online scams, phishing attempts, email fraud, and deceptive websites. Designed for families, seniors, and non-technical readers.
Guidance for parents navigating social media, smartphones, privacy, and online safety with children and teens—focused on trust, awareness, and practical family conversations.
Short, actionable technology tips for seniors, parents, and everyday users. Simple advice to make devices, apps, and online tools safer and easier to use.
Posts that have not yet been assigned to a specific topic category.

Practical Cybersecurity and AI Guidance for Everyday Users

PRACTICAL GUIDES FOR EVERYDAY DIGITAL LIFE

Learn cybersecurity and AI without the jargon or hype.

I’m Grant Ingraham, an engineer-turned-author who writes clear, practical guides for everyday readers—parents, seniors, beginners, and anyone who wants to feel confident online and with modern tools like AI.

If you want straightforward explanations, step-by-step checklists, and real-world examples you can actually use, you are in the right place.

Browse all books Read the latest articles

Get Practical AI & Cybersecurity Updates (No Spam)

If you want clear, practical guidance on AI and cybersecurity—without hype or technical jargon—join my updates list..

I’ll email you when I publish a new article, checklist, or important book update. These are short, useful messages written for everyday users: parents, seniors, and anyone who wants to feel more confident with technology.

Short emails. Practical help. Unsubscribe anytime.

No ads. No selling your email. Ever.

START HERE

Not sure where to start?

Concerned about online safety?

Start with cybersecurity basics: scams, passwords, account protection, privacy, and safer browsing—without technical lectures.

Start with Cybersecurity

Curious about AI you can use today?

Start with simple, reliable ways to use tools like ChatGPT for home, work, and creativity—plus how to write prompts that actually work.

Start with AI

FROM THE BLOG

Recent Articles

Short, practical posts on safer browsing, avoiding scams, using AI responsibly, and building everyday digital confidence.

Deeper Guides

Looking for a deeper, step-by-step guide?

If an article helps, the books go further—organized, comprehensive, and designed for readers who want a clear roadmap.

Cybersecurity: How To Be Secure

For readers who want practical protection for browsing, banking, social media, and shopping—explained in plain language.

item.content:encoded:
Want to see what I'm reading? I have a growing collection on my bookshelf. See My Bookshelf

Explore my growing collection of practical, easy-to-follow guides on AI and cybersecurity for everyday users. Whether you want to get more from today’s AI tools or protect yourself and your family online, these books deliver clear, actionable advice you can use right away. New projects are released regularly, and ARC members get early access to chapters, covers, and launch announcements before anyone else.

Join My ARC Team for Early Access

Featured Book

AI Prompts: Master ChatGPT Fast with Easy Prompts for Home, Work, and Creativity

A practical, step-by-step guide to getting real value from AI—without the jargon.

This hands-on guide shows you exactly how to talk to ChatGPT so it becomes a useful partner in everyday life. Learn to brainstorm ideas, plan, write, solve problems, and help your family—all with simple prompts you can reuse and adapt, even if you don’t consider yourself tech-savvy.

  • Ready-to-use prompts for home, family, and daily tasks
  • Clear, friendly explanations instead of technical jargon
  • Safety tips to avoid scams, misinformation, and bad advice
  • Creative and practical use cases for work, hobbies, and projects
Learn more Buy on Amazon Free Companion: AI Prompt Coach Join My ARC Team

All Books

AI Prompts: Master ChatGPT Fast with Easy Prompts for Home, Work, and Creativity
Make AI useful, safe, and practical in everyday life.

A friendly, example-driven guide that shows you how to get real, practical value from ChatGPT. Learn simple prompting patterns you can apply at home, at work, and in your creative projects—without needing any technical background or special skills.

Learn more Buy on Amazon Free Companion: AI Prompt Coach
Cybersecurity: How To Be Secure — Browsing, Banking, Social Media, Shopping
A plain-language guide to staying safe online.

A straightforward, real-world introduction to online safety for everyday users. Learn how to handle passwords, avoid scams, protect your banking and credit cards, use public Wi-Fi more safely, and keep your identity and devices secure—without needing to be a “computer person.”

Learn more Buy on Amazon

Coming Soon

AI Pocket Guide for Home & Family
Quick, practical prompts in a compact guide.

A handy pocket guide you can open anytime you need simple, effective prompts for home, family life, school projects, and everyday problem-solving. Designed to be small enough to toss in a bag, and clear enough for anyone in the family to use.

Get Advance Notice
Cybersecurity Pocket Guide
Essential safety checklists for everyday users.

A compact guide to everyday cyber hygiene: passwords, banking, email, social media, and mobile device safety. Includes simple checklists you can follow step by step to keep yourself and your family more secure online.

Get Advance Notice

About Grant Ingraham

Grant Ingraham is a retired engineer, consultant, and author focused on helping everyday readers navigate cybersecurity, digital safety, and artificial intelligence. His books aim to make complex topics easy to understand through clear explanations and real-world examples.

Drawing on decades of technical and business experience, Grant helps readers build confidence in a rapidly changing world—so they can use modern tools without feeling overwhelmed or left behind. If you’d like the longer story, you can read it on my About page.

Read Full Bio

Ready to Start Reading?

Choose the book that fits your needs, then join my ARC team to get early access to new chapters, pocket guides, and upcoming releases.

Join My ARC Team

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: Grant Ingraham
item.content:encoded:
About Grant Ingraham

I write calm, practical guides about AI and online safety for everyday people — parents, seniors, beginners, and anyone who feels overwhelmed by modern technology.

I’m an engineer by training and an author by choice. After decades working with technology, safety, and systems that affect real people, I saw a growing problem; technology was advancing faster than everyday understanding.

Parents were worried about their kids online. Seniors were afraid of scams. Beginners felt embarrassed asking basic questions. And most advice available was either overly technical, fear-driven, or written for experts.

I started writing because I believed there was a better way — one built on clarity, patience, and respect for the reader.

Why I Write These Books

My goal is not to make people “experts.” It’s to help them feel confident enough to make good decisions.

That means explaining technology in plain language, avoiding hype and fear, and focusing on practical habits that actually improve safety and understanding.

If a reader finishes one of my books feeling calmer, more informed, and less intimidated by technology, then the book has done its job.

My Books

My writing focuses on two core areas:

  • Cybersecurity for everyday users — protecting yourself from scams, managing passwords, browsing safely, and understanding online risks without technical jargon.
  • Artificial intelligence for beginners — explaining what AI is (and isn’t), how it’s already used in daily life, and how families can approach it safely and responsibly.

You can explore my books and related resources here:

View All Books AI Resources Cybersecurity Resources

Who This Is For

My work is written especially for:

  • Parents and grandparents navigating technology with their families
  • Seniors who want to stay safe and independent online
  • Beginners who want clear explanations without judgment
  • Anyone who prefers calm guidance over hype or fear

item.content:encoded:
Online Safety for Beginners & Practical Protection Tips

Buy on Amazon
Read on Kindle
Leave A Review

A clear, no-nonsense guide to protecting yourself and your family online. Perfect for parents, seniors, beginners, and anyone who wants safe browsing without the tech overwhelm.

Protect your money, identity, and privacy online—without becoming a tech expert.

This beginner-friendly guide shows simple steps for online safety, including how to protect yourself from scams, secure your devices, and reduce identity theft risk when browsing, banking, shopping, or using social media.

Perfect if you’ve ever said…

  • “I’m not technical—I just want simple, safe habits.”
  • “I worry about scams, but I don’t know what to look for.”
  • “I bank and shop online… how do I do it safely?”
  • “My passwords are a mess and I need a better system.”
  • “I want to protect my family without living in fear.”

Designed for everyday users, not IT professionals

  • Seniors who want safe, stress-free browsing
  • Parents who want to protect their children online
  • New computer users learning modern digital safety
  • Anyone who has been scammed—or worried about being scammed
  • Small business owners who want quick, practical guidance
  • People who want simple, everyday steps to reduce risk

What you’ll be able to do after reading

This book teaches the practical, real-world skills that prevent the most common online problems:

  • Spot scams, fake websites, and phishing attacks
  • Protect your passwords and accounts the right way
  • Avoid “too good to be true” offers that steal your data
  • Secure your phone, laptop, and home Wi-Fi
  • Manage privacy settings on Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, and more
  • Identify safe vs. unsafe links, downloads, and email attachments
  • Understand banking security and reduce fraudulent charge risk
  • Keep children and grandchildren safer online with easy-to-follow steps

What’s inside Cybersecurity: How to Be Secure

The book is divided into clear, easy-to-read chapters that help you take control of your online safety immediately.

  • The Foundations of Online Safety
  • Scams, Phishing, and Identity Theft
  • Safe Browsing Habits
  • Banking and Online Purchases
  • Email and Messaging Safety
  • Social Media Protection
  • Home Wi-Fi and Device Security
  • Protecting Children and Grandchildren
  • When Things Go Wrong: What to Do
  • Checklists, Quick Fixes, and Bonus Tools

A few safety tips from inside the book

Use these right away to improve your online security:

  • Never click a link in an email claiming your account is “locked”—log in manually from the official site instead.
  • Use passphrases instead of passwords: something like Mint-Cathedral-Picnic-47.
  • Be suspicious of urgent messages from “friends or family” asking for money—call them directly to confirm.
  • Update your phone and computer when prompted—most updates fix security holes criminals exploit.
  • On public Wi-Fi at coffee shops or airports, avoid logging into banking or shopping accounts.

Free bonus checklists and tools included

Your purchase includes access to downloadable resources to help you stay protected:

  • Security checklists
  • Browser safety settings
  • Social media privacy guides
  • Device security templates
  • Printable scam-spotting cheat sheet

About Grant Ingraham

Grant Ingraham is an engineer, consultant, and educator who has spent decades helping people understand technology without confusing jargon. With real-life stories, simple explanations, and actionable checklists, he teaches beginners how to stay safe and confident online.

Protect yourself and your loved ones online. Start building safe habits today with Cybersecurity: How to Be Secure — Browsing, Banking, Social Media, Shopping.

item.title: AI Prompts
item.dc:creator: Grant Ingraham
item.content:encoded:
Buy the Book On Amazon
Join My ARC, Get A Free Review Copy!

Skip the tech jargon and start using AI today.

If you’ve ever opened ChatGPT and thought, “Now what?”, this book is for you. AI Prompts: Master ChatGPT Fast with Easy Prompts for Home, Work, and Creativity is a hands-on guide written for everyday people—parents, retirees, students, small-business owners, and anyone who wants AI to make life easier, not more confusing. You’ll get step-by-step examples and ready-to-use prompts you can customize in seconds.

Perfect if you’ve ever said…

  • “I’m curious about AI but don’t know where to start.”
  • “I don’t want theory—I want prompts I can actually use.”
  • “I’m not technical. Just show me what to type in.”
  • “I’d love help with writing, planning, brainstorming, and organizing.”
  • “I want AI to save me time at home, at work, and in my creative hobbies.”

What you’ll be able to do with this book

By the time you finish, you’ll know how to talk to ChatGPT like a helpful assistant instead of a mysterious black box. You’ll learn how to:

  • Craft prompts that get clear, useful answers the first time
  • Use AI to draft emails, letters, reports, and summaries
  • Turn vague ideas into outlines, checklists, and action plans
  • Brainstorm blog posts, social media content, book ideas, and more
  • Plan trips, meals, parties, and projects with AI as your assistant
  • Get AI to explain complex topics in plain English
  • Avoid common pitfalls like “hallucinations” and misleading answers

What’s inside AI Prompts

The book is divided into simple, focused sections so you can flip straight to what you need today. Inside, you’ll find:

  • ChatGPT Basics – how to sign up, start a conversation, and stay safe.
  • Prompting 101 – simple formulas so you always know what to type.
  • Home & Everyday Life – prompts for organization, letters, schedules, and problem-solving.
  • Work & Productivity – prompts for emails, reports, meeting notes, and research help.
  • Creativity & Fun – prompts for stories, art ideas, journaling, and hobbies.
  • Troubleshooting & Safety – how to spot AI mistakes and fact-check results.

You’ll have hundreds of example prompts you can copy, paste, and adapt for your own life.

Try a few prompts from the book

Here are just a few examples of the kinds of prompts you’ll find inside:

  • “You are my friendly writing assistant. Help me write a polite email to [person] explaining [situation] in a calm, respectful tone. Keep it under 200 words.”
  • “Help me plan a one-week schedule to work on [goal] 30 minutes per day. Include specific tasks for each day and a simple way to track progress.”
  • “Explain [topic] to me as if I’m 12 years old. Use short paragraphs and everyday examples.”
  • “Give me 10 creative ideas for [project: blog posts / social media posts / book chapter topics] focused on [audience].”

Want interactive help writing prompts?

I built the AI Prompt Coach as a companion to AI Prompts. It helps you turn vague ideas into clear instructions, shows you why a prompt worked (or didn’t), and guides you step by step to better results in ChatGPT.

Learn About the AI Prompt Coach
Open the AI Prompt Coach in ChatGPT

Join My ARC, Get A Free Review Copy!

About Grant Ingraham

Grant Ingraham is an engineer, consultant, and lifelong technologist who has spent decades helping everyday people understand complex tools without the jargon. Now in his late 70s, he’s on a mission to show parents, seniors, and non-technical readers how to use AI in practical, down-to-earth ways—to save time, reduce frustration, and have a little fun along the way.

item.title: Resources
item.dc:creator: Grant Ingraham
item.content:encoded:
Cybersecurity & AI Resources for Everyday Use

Practical guides, downloadable tools, and helpful links to keep you safe online and make AI easier to use every day.

Cybersecurity Tools & Guides

Quick-Start Security Checklists

  • Password & Account Security Checklist (PDF)
  • Home Wi-Fi Safety Checklist (PDF)
  • Online Shopping Safety Guide (PDF)
  • Email Scams: What to Look For
  • Social Media Safety for Families

Recommended Security Tools

  • Password Manager: Bitwarden
  • Two-Factor Authentication App: Authy
  • Malware Protection (Windows/Mac): Malwarebytes
  • Data Breach Check: haveibeenpwned.com
  • Encrypted Messaging: Signal

AI & ChatGPT Resources

AI for Everyday Life: Quick Guides

  • How to Ask Better Questions in ChatGPT
  • Prompts for Home, Work, and Creativity
  • AI Safety Tips for Parents and Seniors (PDF)
  • How to Spot an AI Hallucination

Interactive AI Tool

AI Prompt Coach is an interactive tool I created to help everyday users learn how to write clearer, more effective prompts for tools like ChatGPT. Instead of guessing what to ask, the Coach helps you understand why prompts work and how to improve them step by step.

Built on the same framework I explain in my book AI Prompts, the AI Prompt Coach is especially helpful for beginners, seniors, parents, educators, and anyone who feels frustrated by vague or inconsistent AI results.

Learn About the AI Prompt Coach

Downloadable Prompt Packs

  • 50 Everyday Prompts for Beginners (PDF)
  • AI for Writers – Prompt Toolkit
  • AI for Small Business Owners
  • AI for Students (Study Helpers)
    • AI for Homework & Research
    • AI for Writing & Editing
    • AI for Study & Exam Prep

Book Companion Downloads

Resources that go with my books:

AI Prompts

  • Bonus prompt packs
  • Image-generation templates
  • “AI in One Hour” starter guide
  • Cheat sheet for beginners

If you purchased the book, these extras are included for free.

Cybersecurity

  • Chapter-by-chapter summaries
  • Practice scenarios
  • Printable safety worksheets
  • Scam-spotting examples

Free Downloads

These will be ready for download as PDFs on your site:

  • Cyber Safety Starter Kit
  • AI Beginner’s Quick Guide
  • Safe Social Media Checklist (Parents)
  • Password Strategy Mini-Book
  • Top 20 Online Scams to Watch For (Updated Quarterly)

Helpful External Links

Useful websites for staying informed:

  • FTC Scam Alerts – real-time scam warnings
  • Consumer Reports – Digital Privacy
  • Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA)
  • Identity Theft Resource Center
  • Krebs on Security (plain-English cybersecurity news)

ARC & Early Reader Program

If you would like early access to new books, join my Advance Reader Community (ARC):

  • Get free pre-release copies
  • Give feedback that shapes the final book
  • Receive exclusive behind-the-scenes updates

item.dc:creator: Grant Ingraham
item.content:encoded:
Contact Me by Email

Have a question or request? I’d be glad to hear from you.
Please send me an email using the form below:

Before You Email — Please Read

  • State your main point in the first sentence.
  • If requesting an ARC file, mention your preferred format (EPUB or PDF).
  • Use your real name and a working email address.
  • No attachments or links—these will not be accepted.
  • No advertising or unsolicited pitches—these will be ignored.
  • Please allow up to 24 hours for a reply.

item.title: It's In Your iPhone
item.dc:creator: Grant Ingraham
item.content:encoded:
Every modern iPhone with up‑to‑date iOS uses some form of Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning (AI/ML) in core apps. The most prominent examples include:

  • Siri (virtual assistant)
  • Messages (Genmoji, Smart Reply, Live Translation)
  • Mail (summaries, Smart Reply)
  • Photos (recognition, Memories, search)
  • Notes (summarization)
  • Keyboard & Dictation (predictions, speech‑to‑text)
  • Translate (real‑time language translation)
  • FaceTime & Phone (Live Translation)
  • Shortcuts (contextual automation)

Core iPhone Apps with Built‑in AI/ML Features

  • Siri (Voice Assistant) — Uses AI for natural language understanding, voice queries, context retention, recommendations, and more. Siri’s capabilities include voice recognition, language understanding, and intelligent task execution.
  • Messages — AI‑enhanced features such as Genmoji creation, live translation, Smart Replies, and contextual suggestions.
  • Mail — AI‑powered message summaries, Smart Reply, and intelligent sorting (with Apple Intelligence enabled).
  • Photos — Intelligent photo analysis and recommendations. The Photos app uses machine learning for object/scene recognition, Memories creation, and sorting, enhanced further with Apple Intelligence.
  • Notes — AI‑assisted summarization and text transformation.
  • Keyboard / Dictation — AI‑based typing predictions, autocorrect, and speech‑to‑text. The system keyboard uses language models to improve autocorrect and predictive text; Dictation uses on‑device speech‑to‑text models.
  • Translate — AI‑driven language translation using neural models for text and voice translations.
  • FaceTime — Live Translation captions and intelligent audio features.
  • Shortcuts — Intelligent action suggestions and automation that can be AI‑enhanced.
  • Phone/Calling features — AI‑augmented Live Translation and transcription enhancements.

System‑Wide AI/ML Capabilities Impacting Multiple Built‑In Apps

  • Apple Intelligence — Built‑in AI system that provides generative and analytical capabilities used across apps like Mail, Messages, Photos, Notes, Translate, and more.
  • On‑Device Machine Learning and Core ML — Underlying frameworks used by native apps for features such as object recognition, suggestions, and personalization.
  • Live Text & Visual Recognition — System AI that lets you extract text from images and interact with it (works in Photos, Camera, Safari, and other apps).

item.title: Prompts for Schoolwork
item.dc:creator: mikelgililland
item.content:encoded:
AI Prompts for Parents Helping Teens With Schoolwork (Without Cheating)

Many parents want to help their teens with school—but feel stuck. Assignments can be confusing, subjects change, and when AI enters the picture, it’s easy to worry about the line between supporting learning and doing the work.

This page gives you safe, practical AI prompts you can use to help your teen understand schoolwork, get unstuck, and build confidence—without shortcuts or replacing real learning.

  • Parents
  • Grandparents
  • Caregivers
  • Non-technical families
  • Teens who feel overwhelmed
Try the AI Prompt Coach Read: AI for Beginners (Start Here)

On this page

  • How parents should use AI for schoolwork support
  • 7 safe prompts (with why they work)
  • Safety and integrity guidelines
  • Guided help (Prompt Coach)
  • Where to go next

How Parents Should Use AI for Schoolwork Support

Used responsibly, AI can act like a patient tutor or study guide. It should support thinking, not replace it.

AI can help as a:

  • Patient tutor (explaining concepts in new ways)
  • Study guide (practice questions and review)
  • Clarity tool (rephrasing confusing directions)
  • Planning aid (breaking assignments into steps)

AI should not be used as:

  • An answer machine for graded work
  • A shortcut that bypasses learning
  • A replacement for effort or honesty

Rule of thumb: Ask AI to explain, coach, or quiz—not to “solve.”

If your teen could not explain the answer out loud, the work is not truly theirs yet.

7 Safe Prompts Parents Can Use (With “Why It Works” + “Watch Out For”)

These prompts are designed to keep your teen involved and learning. Replace the bracketed parts with your situation.

Prompt 1: Explain a Concept at a Teen’s Level

Use this when: Your teen doesn’t understand a topic, even after reading the assignment.

Prompt

Explain this concept in simple terms for a [grade level] student. Assume no prior background. Use two everyday examples and a short summary at the end.
Topic: [insert topic]

Why this works: AI is strong at rephrasing explanations at different difficulty levels.

Watch out for: Explanations can be oversimplified or incomplete. Encourage follow-up questions.

Prompt 2: Help a Teen Get Unstuck (Without Giving the Answer)

Use this when: Your teen understands part of the problem but doesn’t know the next step.

Prompt

Act like a tutor. Help a student think through the next step without giving the final answer. Ask me 2–3 questions first to see what I already understand.
Problem description: [describe the assignment]

Why this works: It forces coaching and questioning instead of solution-dumping.

Watch out for: If the AI starts solving, stop and say: “No final answer—only hints and questions.”

Prompt 3: Turn an Assignment Into a Simple Study Plan

Use this when: Your teen feels overwhelmed and doesn’t know where to start.

Prompt

Break this assignment into 6–10 manageable steps a student can follow. Include suggested time estimates and checkpoints to confirm understanding.
Assignment: [paste or summarize]

Why this works: AI is excellent at organizing tasks into clear sequences.

Watch out for: Time estimates may be unrealistic—adjust to your teen’s schedule and pace.

Prompt 4: Rephrase Confusing Directions in Plain English

Use this when: Instructions feel unclear, overly academic, or vague.

Prompt

Rewrite these assignment instructions in plain English for a student. Then list the required deliverables as a checklist.
Instructions: [paste here]

Why this works: AI is strong at translating formal language into everyday language.

Watch out for: If requirements are still unclear, verify with the teacher rather than guessing.

Prompt 5: Practice for a Test (Questions + Feedback)

Uses this when: Your teen wants to review material without being “taught at.”

Prompt

Quiz me with 10 practice questions on [topic] at a [grade level]. After each answer, tell me what I did well and what to review. Keep feedback encouraging.
Topic: [insert topic]

Why this works: Retrieval practice builds real understanding and memory.

Watch out for: Questions may not match the exact curriculum—use as practice, not prophecy.

Prompt 6: Check Understanding (Without Solving)

Use this when: You want to confirm whether your teen understands the concept.

Prompt

Ask me 8 questions that test understanding of [topic]. Do not give answers unless I ask. If I’m confused, offer a hint and a simpler explanation.
Topic: [insert topic]

Why this works: It keeps the teen thinking and explaining—key to real learning.

Watch out for: Encourage your teen to answer in their own words, not “repeat the AI.”

Prompt 7: Explain “Why This Method Works”

Use this when: Your teen can follow steps but doesn’t understand the reasoning.

Prompt

Explain why this method works, step by step, in a way a [grade level] student can understand. Include one simple example and one common mistake to avoid.
Method/problem type: [describe]

Why this works: Understanding “why” improves retention and reduces dependence.

Watch out for: AI can be confidently wrong—verify with the textbook or teacher notes when needed.

Safety and Integrity Guidelines for Parents

AI can support learning, but it can also undermine it if used as a shortcut. These guidelines keep your family on solid ground:

  • Follow school policies on AI use (they vary widely).
  • Don’t submit AI-generated work as the student’s original work.
  • Keep your teen involved: ask them to explain what they learned out loud.
  • Verify important facts with the textbook, teacher materials, or reliable sources.
  • Avoid sensitive data: do not paste names, student IDs, medical details, or private information.
Read: AI Basics and Safe Use

Want Guided Help Instead of Guessing?

If you’d like step-by-step guidance on writing safe, effective prompts—especially for family and learning situations—the AI Prompt Coach provides interactive help designed for everyday use. It focuses on clarity, safety, and understanding—not shortcuts.

Try the AI Prompt Coach Revisit AI Basics

Where to Go Next

If you’d like to go deeper, choose your next step:

  • AI for Beginners — understand what AI is, what it can’t do, and how to use it safely.
  • AI Prompts Book — beginner-friendly prompts and guidance for everyday situations.
  • AI Blog Posts — articles and tips to build confidence over time.

Editorial note: This page is educational and not a substitute for school policies, teacher guidance, or academic integrity rules.

item.title: The Many Faces of Facebook - Part 2
item.dc:creator: mikelgililland
item.content:encoded:
Part 1 explained the five views and how to reach them. This page explains the deeper reason each view exists, and why it matters for privacy, credibility, growth, and long-term control.

Jump to a section:

  1. Why My Profile matters
  2. Why Page View matters
  3. Why Home (as Page) matters
  4. Why the Professional Dashboard matters
  5. Why Search view matters
  6. Why there are so many ways to reach “the same” place
  7. The simple mental model

1) Why My Profile matters — protecting the human behind the work

Your profile is not “just another page.” It is the private identity layer that anchors everything else you do on Facebook.

  • Privacy boundary: Your profile is where personal relationships and everyday life can remain private, separate from public publishing.
  • Platform legitimacy: Facebook requires a real personal profile to manage a Page. This ties accountability to public publishing and reduces impersonation.
  • Emotional sustainability: A personal space protects you from brand pressure and keeps public feedback from spilling into personal relationships.

2) Why Page View matters — public trust and authority

Your Page is where your identity becomes mission. It’s the layer designed for broad visibility and consistent public voice.

  • Credibility signal: A Page communicates “this is a creator/author presence,” which increases trust compared to a personal profile.
  • Scalable growth: Pages are built for followers, sharing, and discovery—critical if you want new readers to find you.
  • Brand consistency: Your bio, tone, and purpose are presented as a stable public identity people can recognize quickly.

3) Why Home (as Page) matters — operating in the public network

When you are on Home while acting as the Page, you are operating as a public voice. That shift changes how you engage and what you learn.

  • Audience awareness: You see what other Pages do, what formats work, and how topics travel—useful informal market research.
  • Reputation-safe engagement: Commenting as the Page encourages more intentional, calmer interaction because it’s public-facing by design.
  • Community positioning: Your Page identity becomes part of a wider network of public ideas rather than a private circle of friends.

4) Why the Professional Dashboard matters — where visibility becomes measurable reality

The dashboard is the control room. It turns “posting” into “publishing,” and guesswork into evidence.

  • Truth over intuition: Reach, engagement, and growth become visible metrics, not assumptions.
  • Strategic improvement: You can refine topics, posting times, and formats based on what performs.
  • Ownership mindset: Tools and insights encourage a long-term approach: repeat what works, drop what doesn’t, and build consistency.

5) Why Search view matters — the first impression you don’t control

Search is the public’s entry point. It’s how strangers discover you, and how they decide—quickly—whether you are worth following.

  • Discovery gateway: People often search after hearing your name or seeing your work shared elsewhere.
  • Reputation snapshot: In seconds, visitors judge activity level, clarity, and professionalism from the preview.
  • Trust before relationship: Non-friends rely on signals. A calm, consistent presence makes “follow” feel safe.

Why are there so many ways to see what looks like the same page?

Facebook isn’t duplicating pages—it’s switching your role and perspective. Similar content appears in different views because the platform must support different goals at the same time.

Three layers operating at once

  1. Identity layer: personal Profile vs public Page (different audiences and rules).
  2. Perspective layer: viewing as yourself, as the Page, or as the public (different permissions and visibility).
  3. Management layer: publishing/analytics tools (Dashboard) vs discovery surfaces (Search).

What feels redundant is really role-based architecture designed to support:

  • privacy (protect the human account),
  • publishing (support a public voice),
  • growth (analytics and tools),
  • discovery (help strangers find you).

The simple mental model

  • Profile = person (private life + personal connections)
  • Page = public brand (author voice + followers)
  • Home as Page = operating environment (how your Page interacts socially)
  • Professional Dashboard = control panel (tools + analytics)
  • Search view = storefront (first impression + discovery)

Once you see Facebook as a system of roles, the “duplicate” screens stop feeling duplicate. They’re simply different rooms in the same building.

← Previous: The Five Views (What They Are)

item.title: The Many Faces of Facebook - Part 1
item.dc:creator: mikelgililland
item.content:encoded:
If you manage both a personal identity and a public author identity on Facebook, as I do, you’ll often feel like you’re seeing “the same page” in multiple places. You aren’t. Facebook is showing different views of the same underlying presence—each view has its own purpose, permissions, and audience.

This page covers the five common views and how you reach each one:

  1. My Profile (Michael Gililland)
  2. Page View (Grant Ingraham)
  3. Home Feed (while acting as the Page)
  4. Professional Dashboard
  5. Search Result View

In Part 2, we’ll explain why these views matter and why Facebook has so many paths that seem to lead to the same place.

1) My Profile — the personal identity layer

What it is: Your personal profile (Michael Gililland) is your private, human identity on Facebook. This is where friendships, personal interactions, and everyday life typically live.

How it is reached: You arrive here by default when you log into Facebook. You can typically return to it by clicking your profile picture in the top-right area of Facebook.

2) Page View — the public author identity (Grant Ingraham)

What it is: Your Facebook Page is your public-facing author identity. It’s designed for followers (not friends), broad visibility, and a consistent public voice.

How it is reached (your two common paths):

  1. From your personal profile, switch your identity to “Grant Ingraham” (acting as the Page).
  2. Once on the Page environment, click the Grant Ingraham profile image (top-left area) to land on the main Page view.

3) Home Feed (as the Page) — your Page’s social operating view

What it is: This is the Home feed experience while you are acting as the Page. It’s not the same as your personal feed. It’s Facebook’s attempt to give your Page a “social environment” of its own.

How it is reached: While on the Grant Ingraham Page identity, click the Home button/icon.

4) Professional Dashboard — the management and analytics center

What it is: The Professional Dashboard is where Facebook puts tools that treat your Page like a public-facing property: insights, settings, distribution tools, and performance tracking.

How it is reached: From the Grant Ingraham Page, select Professional dashboard.

5) Search Result View — how people discover your Page

What it is: This is the discovery view. Someone can search “Grant Ingraham” and encounter your Page as a first impression.

How it is reached: Search for “Grant Ingraham” from any Facebook context (another profile, another page, or your own Home feed).

Next: Why These Views Matter →

Join my Advance Reader Community (ARC) and updates list. You’ll get early access to new AI and cybersecurity books, previews, and practical guides—plus a simple way to share feedback that helps shape the final release.

Join the ARC & Updates List

Enter your email to receive early copies when available, along with occasional publication updates. No hype. No spam.

Short emails. Practical help. Unsubscribe anytime. No ads. No selling your email.

If you already have a WordPress.com account, email delivery may default to paused. After confirming your subscription, please make sure email delivery is enabled in your WordPress subscription settings.

Your feedback helps shape books built for real families, seniors, and everyday readers.

If you enjoy practical, easy-to-read books about AI, cybersecurity, and everyday technology, I’d love to have you in my ARC. As an ARC reader, you may receive early chapters or full review copies (when available) and you’ll have an opportunity to offer helpful feedback before publication.

How It Works

  • Sign up with your email above.
  • Receive early chapters or ARC copies of upcoming AI and cybersecurity books (when available).
  • Share honest feedback to help improve clarity, accuracy, and usefulness.
  • Leave an honest review at launch to help other readers choose wisely.

Joining is completely free—no fees, no commitments.

What You’ll Receive as an ARC Reader

When you join, you’ll be among the first to see what I’m working on—while helping shape the final version of each book.

  • Early digital copies of new books before launch (when available)
  • A chance to offer comments, corrections, and suggestions
  • Behind-the-scenes updates about what I’m writing next
  • Review reminders and direct links when a book goes live

Join the Updates List Browse all books

What I Ask From You

I want this to be simple and enjoyable. Here’s all I ask of ARC members:

  • Read the book (or as much as you reasonably can) before launch.
  • Share honest feedback if you spot errors or confusing sections.
  • Post an honest review on Amazon (and optionally Goodreads) when the book is released.
  • Note that you received a free ARC copy if required by review guidelines.

Who I Am

I’m Grant Ingraham, a retired engineer and author of practical, easy-to-understand books on AI, cybersecurity, and everyday technology. My goal is to help real people—not tech experts—use modern tools with confidence and stay safe online.

Is This ARC Right for You?

You’ll be a great fit for this ARC if you:

  • Enjoy practical, down-to-earth books about technology
  • Are curious about AI or online safety—even if you don’t consider yourself “techy”
  • Are willing to read digital formats (PDF or Kindle-ready file)
  • Can leave a short, honest review at launch

Current & Upcoming ARC Titles

  • Cybersecurity: How to Be Secure — Browsing, Banking, Social Media, Shopping
  • AI Prompts: Master ChatGPT Fast with Easy Prompts for Home, Work, and Creativity
  • Pocket Guides on AI and tech topics — Coming Soon

After you sign up, watch for a confirmation email. You’ll need to confirm to be added to the list.

Short emails. Practical help. Unsubscribe anytime. No ads. No selling your email.

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: mikelgililland
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: https://grantingraham.me.

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where your data is sent

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Grant Ingraham Media Kit

Grant Ingraham is the pen name of Michael Gililland, an engineer and lifelong technical communicator with decades of public speaking experience.

With a career centered on public speaking and instruction, he helps audiences cut through hype, reduce fear, and build confidence with modern technology.

Download Full Media Kit (PDF) PDF • 5 MB • 7 Pages

Quick Facts

  • Name: Grant Ingraham
  • Location: Oxford, Mississippi, USA
  • Primary Topics: Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity
  • Best For: General audiences, beginners, non-technical users, adults 55+, lifelong learners
  • Media Contact: info@grantingraham.me
  • Website: https://grantingraham.me
  • Goodreads: https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/58043779.Grant_Ingraham
  • Amazon Author Page: https://www.amazon.com/author/grantingraham

Author Bio (Copy/Paste)

Short Bio (75 words)

Grant Ingraham is an engineer, author, and lifelong technical communicator who has spent more than five decades explaining complex technical subjects to people of all ages. He has written hundreds of consumer manuals and helped business leaders, judges, engineers, and the general public understand science and technology with clarity. Retired now, Grant has turned his expertise toward artificial intelligence. His latest book, AI Prompts, teaches everyone how to use AI safely, confidently, and productively.

Long Bio (182 words)

Grant Ingraham is an engineer, author, and veteran technical communicator who has spent more than 50 years translating complex ideas into clear, practical guidance for ordinary people. Since 1973, his work has focused on helping non-technical audiences understand subjects that often feel intimidating—from writing hundreds of owner’s manuals for consumer products to explaining physics, engineering, and safety concepts to audiences everywhere.

His career includes consulting with federal, state, local, and international agencies such as the CPSC, NFPA, and USPTO; educating business leaders, attorneys, judges, and engineers; and writing standards and instructional materials used across industries. In the computer field, Grant programmed, maintained, operated, and sold a wide range of computing systems, developing complete software packages for both businesses and individuals while continually teaching users how to get the most from their technology.

Since retiring in 2012, Grant has devoted himself to studying, using, and writing about artificial intelligence. His latest book, AI Prompts, serves as a beginner’s guide that walks readers from their very first interaction with ChatGPT to confident, safe, and productive AI use.

Today, Grant is committed to correcting misinformation about AI and helping everyday people understand it as what it truly is: a powerful tool that must be understood to be used well.

Note for hosts/interviewers: Grant is new to promoting his books through media appearances, but brings decades of professional public speaking and instructional experience.

Official Author Photo

Books

AI Prompts - Master ChatGPT Fast With Easy Prompts For Home, Work, And Creativity

Format: 168 pages, Paperback | Publication Date: December 8, 2025 | ISBN: 979-8274069939

AI Prompts is a practical, beginner-friendly guide designed to help everyday users understand how to communicate effectively with artificial intelligence tools such as ChatGPT. Written by Grant Ingraham, an engineer and lifelong educator, the book cuts through technical jargon and hype to explain what prompts are, why they matter, and how small changes in wording can dramatically improve AI responses. Using clear examples, real-world scenarios, and step-by-step techniques, AI Prompts empowers readers—especially seniors, parents, educators, and first-time AI users—to use AI confidently, responsibly, and productively at home, at work, and in creative pursuits, without needing any technical background.

Key Takeaways

  • The quality of an AI’s output depends directly on the quality of the prompt. Clear, specific, and well-structured prompts consistently produce more useful, accurate, and relevant results than vague or casual requests.
  • You do not need technical skills to use AI effectively. Anyone can achieve strong results by learning a few practical prompt patterns that guide AI behavior, tone, and level of detail.
  • Context is critical. Providing background information, goals, and constraints helps AI respond in ways that are aligned with real-world needs rather than generic answers.
  • AI is a tool, not an authority. The book emphasizes reviewing, questioning, and verifying AI outputs, reinforcing responsible use and human judgment.
  • Good prompts improve productivity across everyday tasks. From writing, learning, and planning to problem-solving and creativity, thoughtful prompting saves time and reduces frustration in daily life.

Ideal For

AI Prompts is ideal for beginners, seniors, parents, educators, and everyday users who want to understand and use artificial intelligence confidently, responsibly, and effectively—without technical jargon or prior experience.

View on Amazon Read a Sample

Cybersecurity: How To Be Secure – Browsing, Banking, Social Media, Shopping

Format: 134 pages, Paperback and Kindle | Publication Date: July 31, 2025 | ISBN: 979-8272964557

Cybersecurity: How To Be Secure – Browsing, Banking, Social Media, Shopping is a practical, plain-language guide written for everyday users who want to stay safe online without becoming technical experts. Drawing on decades of experience explaining complex technology to non-technical audiences, Grant Ingraham breaks down modern cybersecurity risks into clear, understandable concepts and realistic habits anyone can follow. The book focuses on real-world threats people actually face—email scams, unsafe websites, weak passwords, online banking risks, and social media exposure—and explains what to do, what to avoid, and why it matters.

Key Takeaways

  • Cybersecurity is about habits, not fear. Small, consistent actions dramatically reduce risk.
  • Most attacks target people, not computers. Understanding scams and manipulation is critical.
  • You don’t need technical expertise to stay safe online. Awareness and common sense go a long way.
  • Everyday activities carry different levels of risk. Browsing, banking, email, and social media require different precautions.
  • Good security improves confidence. Knowing what to do reduces anxiety and confusion.

Ideal For

This book is ideal for adults 55+, beginners, parents, families, and non-technical users who want clear, trustworthy guidance on staying safe online without jargon, fear-based messaging, or technical overwhelm.

View on Amazon Read a Sample

Areas of Expertise & Discussion Topics

Grant is available for interviews and discussions focused on practical, non-technical explanations of AI and cybersecurity. His areas of expertise center on helping everyday people understand and use complex technology with confidence rather than fear. Drawing on decades of experience as an engineer, educator, and technical communicator, his discussion topics focus on practical, real-world guidance in artificial intelligence, prompt writing, and cybersecurity for non-technical audiences. His presentations emphasize clarity, responsibility, and usability, showing how AI tools can be used safely and productively by families, seniors, parents, educators, and professionals—without hype, jargon, or intimidation.

Speaking & Interview Background

Public speaking and instruction were central to Grant’s career. He has extensive experience explaining complex technical subjects to non-technical audiences in clear, practical language. While he is new to promoting his books through media appearances, he is comfortable with interviews, Q&A, panels, and educational discussions.

Writing & Commentary

Grant Ingraham writes for people who want clear answers, not technical noise. His work is grounded in decades of explaining complex subjects to non-technical audiences, with a focus on practicality, safety, and everyday usefulness. Whether addressing artificial intelligence, prompt writing, or cybersecurity, his writing translates emerging technology into plain language, actionable guidance that readers can immediately apply at home, at work, and in their communities.

AI Prompt Coach: Learn How to Write Better Prompts for ChatGPT

The AI Prompt Coach teaches beginners and everyday users how to write clear, effective prompts for AI tools like ChatGPT—without jargon, programming, or trial-and-error frustration. Most frustration with AI does not come from the technology itself. It comes from unclear instructions. When prompts are vague, AI responses are vague. Clear prompts produce clear results. Launch the AI Prompt Coach

What Is the AI Prompt Coach?

The AI Prompt Coach is a custom ChatGPT-based assistant designed to help you learn how to ask better questions so you get better answers from AI. Instead of simply responding to prompts, the Coach explains why a prompt works or fails, helps you rewrite it, and guides you toward clearer, more effective wording.
  • Understand how AI interprets instructions
  • Fix vague or ineffective prompts
  • Write prompts for learning, writing, work, or creativity
  • Reduce hallucinations and irrelevant answers
  • Build confidence using AI responsibly

Why I Created the AI Prompt Coach

For more than fifty years, my work has focused on explaining complex technical ideas to non-technical audiences—through manuals, training, consulting, and testimony. Artificial intelligence presents the same challenge. Most people do not need hype or buzzwords. They need plain-language explanations and practical guidance. The AI Prompt Coach was built as a teaching tool, not a novelty. It reflects the same philosophy found in my book AI Prompts: AI is most useful when you understand how to communicate with it.

Learn the Prompting Method Behind the Coach

The AI Prompt Coach is based on the same framework explained in my book, AI Prompts. The Coach helps you apply the method interactively, while the book explains the concepts in depth. Together, they provide a complete foundation for using AI tools thoughtfully, safely, and effectively. Buy AI Prompts on Amazon

How to Use the AI Prompt Coach

Step 1: Describe Your Goal

Tell the Coach what you want to accomplish. You do not need perfect wording.
  • “Help me write a better AI prompt.”
  • “Why didn’t my ChatGPT prompt work?”
  • “Explain a complex topic for beginners.”
  • “Rewrite this prompt to get clearer results.”

Step 2: Follow the Guidance

The Coach will ask clarifying questions, suggest improvements, and explain the logic behind each revision.

Step 3: Refine and Reuse

Over time, you will learn how to write effective prompts on your own and reduce wasted time correcting AI output.

Who the AI Prompt Coach Is For

  • AI beginners and first-time users
  • Seniors and late adopters
  • Parents and educators
  • Writers, bloggers, and content creators
  • Small business owners
  • Anyone frustrated by trial-and-error prompting
No technical background or programming experience is required.

Start Using the AI Prompt Coach

Access the AI Prompt Coach directly on ChatGPT: Launch the AI Prompt Coach
Learning AI is not about memorizing commands. It is about learning how to think clearly and communicate intent. The AI Prompt Coach exists to make that process understandable, calm, and productive. — Grant Ingraham

item.title: Artificial Intelligence
item.dc:creator: Grant Ingraham
item.content:encoded:
AI for Beginners: A Practical, Safe Introduction

Artificial intelligence has become part of everyday life almost overnight. It writes emails, answers questions, summarizes documents, and even holds conversations. For many people, that speed of change has created excitement— but also confusion and unease.

This page is written for readers who want to understand AI without hype, fear, or technical jargon. You do not need a background in computers or programming to follow along.

The goal is simple: to help you understand what AI is, what it can and cannot do, and how to use it safely and responsibly.

This is not a sales pitch, a technical manual, or a prediction about the future. It is a practical guide for people who want clarity.

What Artificial Intelligence Really Is (In Plain English)

Despite the name, artificial intelligence does not think, reason, or understand the world the way humans do.

At its core, modern AI—tools like ChatGPT—is a pattern-recognition system. It analyzes enormous amounts of existing text and learns statistical relationships between words, phrases, and ideas. When you ask a question, it predicts what a helpful answer should look like based on patterns it has seen before.

That is an important distinction.

AI does not:

  • Know whether something is true
  • Understand meaning in a human sense
  • Have intent, beliefs, or awareness

It produces responses that sound intelligent because language itself follows patterns. When those patterns are strong, the results can be remarkably useful. When they are weak or incomplete, the output can be misleading.

This is why AI can sound confident even when it is wrong. So the safe habit is: treat outputs as drafts—then verify.

What AI Does Well—and Where It Fails

Understanding AI’s strengths and weaknesses is the key to using it effectively.

What AI Does Well

AI is particularly good at:

  • Summarizing large amounts of text
  • Organizing information
  • Drafting emails, letters, and outlines
  • Explaining unfamiliar topics at a high level
  • Rewriting or refining existing content

These tasks rely heavily on pattern recognition, which is exactly what AI is designed to do.

Where AI Falls Short

AI struggles with:

  • Verifying facts
  • Understanding real-world context
  • Making judgments that require experience or ethics
  • Handling ambiguous or poorly defined questions
  • Questions that require current facts or personal judgment

AI does not “check” its work. If incorrect information fits a plausible pattern, it may present it confidently. This is not dishonesty—it is a limitation of how the technology works.

For this reason, AI should be treated as an assistant, not an authority.

Why the Way You Ask Matters

One of the most common frustrations people experience with AI is getting vague or unhelpful answers. In most cases, the problem is not the tool—it is the prompt.

A prompt is simply the instruction you give the AI.

Vague prompts produce vague answers. Clear prompts produce far better results.

For example:

  • Vague: “Tell me about retirement.”
  • Specific: “Explain retirement planning basics for a 70-year-old with no investing background.”

AI responds best when you:

  • Provide context
  • State your goal
  • Identify your audience
  • Ask for a specific format

This skill—learning how to talk to AI effectively—is more important than understanding how AI is built.

Here is a simple starter prompt you can tailor to your needs: You are a [role]. Help me [goal]. My situation is [context]. Output as [format].

See practical AI examples and prompts

Is AI Safe? Addressing Common Concerns

Concerns about AI are reasonable. New technologies have always raised questions about safety, misuse, and unintended consequences.

Privacy

AI tools may store or analyze interactions. You should never enter:

  • Social Security numbers
  • Bank account details
  • Medical records
  • Passwords or private credentials

Treat AI conversations as you would email or online forms.

Accuracy

AI can produce incorrect information that sounds believable. Important facts should always be verified using reliable sources, especially for:

  • Medical decisions
  • Financial decisions
  • Legal matters

Control and Autonomy

AI does not act on its own. It responds only when prompted. It does not have goals, intentions, or independent agency.

Fear often arises from misunderstanding what AI is—and what it is not.

Safe Defaults

  • Use a separate email for signups (optional)
  • Turn off chat history / training if available (platform-dependent)
  • Don’t paste full documents with personal data

Practical, Everyday Uses of AI

When used appropriately, AI can be a genuinely helpful everyday tool.

Common, safe uses include:

  • Drafting and improving emails
  • Summarizing articles or documents
  • Planning trips or schedules
  • Explaining unfamiliar concepts
  • Generating ideas or outlines

In each case, the human remains in control. AI provides assistance; you make the decisions.

How to Start Using AI Responsibly

If you are new to AI, a few simple habits will prevent most problems:

  1. Be specific when asking questions
  2. Verify important information
  3. Avoid sharing sensitive data
  4. Use AI to support thinking, not replace it
  5. Slow down when answers feel too confident—ask: “What are the assumptions?” and “What sources support this?”

Used this way, AI becomes a tool for clarity—not confusion.

item.title: Cybersecurity for Beginners
item.dc:creator: Grant Ingraham
item.content:encoded:
Cybersecurity: How to Be Safer Online (Without the Jargon)

Cybersecurity is not about becoming paranoid—it’s about reducing risk with a few repeatable habits. This page is your hub for practical steps you can take today, plus a guided map to deeper topics like passwords, scams, banking safety, social media, and shopping online.

  • Parents
  • Seniors
  • Beginners
  • Small business owners
  • Anyone tired of scams

On this page

  • Quick Start Checklist
  • Foundations: How Attacks Really Work
  • Passwords & Account Protection
  • Scams, Phishing & Social Engineering
  • Device Safety: Phones, PCs, Wi-Fi
  • Banking & Payments
  • Social Media & Privacy
  • Shopping Online & Avoiding Counterfeits
  • Identity Theft & Recovery Plan
  • Recommended Tools & Resources
  • FAQ

Quick Start Checklist: 10 High-Impact Security Wins

If you do nothing else, do these. They reduce your risk immediately—without needing technical knowledge.

  1. Turn on multi-factor authentication (MFA) for email and banking.
  2. Use a password manager and stop reusing passwords.
  3. Update your phone and computer (automatic updates on).
  4. Lock your phone with a strong PIN (not 1234) and enable biometrics.
  5. Back up important photos and documents (cloud + one local copy).
  6. Pause before clicking links in email/text—go to the site directly instead.
  7. Check bank/credit statements weekly (set alerts where possible).
  8. Secure your home Wi-Fi (unique router password; WPA2/WPA3).
  9. Review privacy settings on social media and limit public info.
  10. Make a recovery plan (what to do if an account is compromised).

Want this as a printable one-page checklist?

I can provide a PDF version for your family or workplace.

Download Checklist (PDF)

Foundations: How Attacks Work (So You Can Stop Them)

Most online attacks succeed for the same reason: they bypass technology by exploiting people. When you understand the patterns, you stop being surprised—and you start spotting danger early.

The 3 Things Attackers Want

  • Your identity (SSN, DOB, accounts)
  • Your money (banking, cards, payments)
  • Your access (email, phone number, logins)

The 4 Common Paths In

  • Phishing links and fake logins
  • Stolen/reused passwords
  • Infected downloads and fake updates
  • Social engineering (urgency, fear, authority)

Your Best Defense

  • Slow down and verify
  • Use MFA everywhere it matters
  • Unique passwords via a manager
  • Backups + recovery steps
Download Cybersecurity Basics Guidelines (PDF)

Passwords & Account Protection

Password reuse is the #1 reason ordinary people get hacked. The fix is straightforward; a password manager plus MFA, starting with your email account.

What to do

  • Choose a password manager and use it daily.
  • Turn on MFA for email, banking, and social accounts.
  • Replace reused passwords with unique ones (start with your most important accounts).
  • Enable account alerts for new logins and password changes.

What to avoid

  • Reusing “one good password” everywhere.
  • Keeping passwords in notes, spreadsheets, or on paper near your computer.
  • Using SMS MFA when better options exist (authenticator apps or security keys).

Cybersecurity Articles (Coming Soon!)

  • How Password Managers Work (and which features matter)
  • MFA Explained: Text vs App vs Security Keys
  • Protect Your Email: The One Account That Unlocks All Others
Download Passwords Starter Guide (PDF) Join ARC for Updates

Scams, Phishing & Social Engineering

Scam messages are engineered to create urgency: “Your account will be closed,” “You owe money,” “Act now.” The winning move is to slow down, verify independently, and never “resolve” issues through a link in a message.

Red Flags

  • Urgency, threats, or “limited time” pressure
  • Requests for codes, gift cards, crypto, wire transfers
  • “Your package is delayed” with a random link
  • Unusual sender addresses or misspellings

Safe Verification

  • Type the website yourself (don’t click)
  • Call the number on the back of your card
  • Use the official app, not email links
  • Ask a trusted person before acting

Family Protection

  • Create a family “verification phrase”
  • Agree: no money transfers under pressure
  • Teach kids the same red flags
  • Set financial alerts on accounts
Read: Spotting Phishing (Cluster) Read: What to Do If You Clicked

Device Safety: Phones, Computers, and Home Wi-Fi

Your phone and email are the “master keys” to your digital life. Secure those first, then secure your network.

Phone essentials

  • Use a strong passcode; enable Face ID / Touch ID.
  • Turn on automatic updates.
  • Review app permissions (location, contacts, photos).
  • Enable “Find My” (iPhone) / “Find My Device” (Android).

Computer essentials

  • Automatic OS and browser updates.
  • Use reputable anti-malware (or built-in protections kept updated).
  • Install software only from trusted sources.
  • Backups: at least one offline/local copy.

Home Wi-Fi essentials

  • Change the router admin password (not the Wi-Fi name/password).
  • Use WPA2/WPA3; avoid WEP.
  • Disable WPS if you don’t need it.
  • Create a guest network for visitors and smart devices.

Cybersecurity Articles (Coming Soon!)

  • Home Security for Non-Technical Users
  • Secure Your Router in 15 Minutes
  • Backups: The Simple Plan That Saves You

Banking & Payments: Reduce Fraud Risk Without Losing Convenience

Your best tools are alerts, strong authentication, and a consistent routine for reviewing activity. The goal is early detection and fast response.

High-Impact Settings

  • Transaction alerts (text/app/email)
  • MFA on bank and email accounts
  • Credit card virtual numbers (if offered)
  • Daily/weekly account review

Payment Safety

  • Use credit cards for online purchases when possible
  • Avoid wire transfers and gift cards
  • Verify payees independently
  • Keep receipts and confirmation emails

When Something Looks Wrong

  • Call the official number (card back / bank site)
  • Change passwords from a clean device
  • Freeze card / dispute quickly
  • Document dates, times, and actions

Safe Banking Articles

  • Safe Banking Online (Coming Soon)
  • Venmo/Cash App/Zelle Safety (Coming Soon)

Social Media & Privacy: Share Less, Control More

Social platforms are useful—but they are also rich sources of personal data used in scams and account takeovers. The goal is not to quit; it’s to control what you share and who can reach you.

Privacy moves that matter

  • Limit who can see your posts and personal details.
  • Hide your friend list (when possible).
  • Disable/limit DMs from strangers.
  • Remove old posts that reveal birthdates, addresses, routines.

Account protection

  • Unique password + MFA.
  • Review logged-in sessions/devices.
  • Be skeptical of “friend” requests from familiar names.

Privacy Articles (Coming Soon)

  • Privacy Settings: The Simple Walkthrough
  • Impersonation Scams: “Is This Really You?”
  • What Not to Post (and why scammers love it)
Get the Privacy Checkup Guide Learn More in the Book

Shopping Online: Avoid Fraud, Fake Sites, and Counterfeits

Online shopping is convenient, but it’s full of traps: fake storefronts, “too good to be true” prices, and look-alike websites. A few verification habits prevent most losses.

Verify the Seller

  • Look for a real address and support contact
  • Search the store name + “reviews” + “scam”
  • Be cautious with brand-new domains
  • Use payment methods with protections

Watch for Fake Sites

  • Misspelled domains (look closely)
  • Odd checkout behavior or forced “account creation”
  • Unusual payment demands (gift cards, crypto)
  • Heavy pressure: “Only 3 left!” everywhere

Safer Habits

  • Use a dedicated shopping email alias (optional)
  • Virtual card numbers (if available)
  • Save order confirmations
  • Set delivery alerts
    Shopping Articles (Coming Soon)
  • Shopping Online Safely
    • li>
  • Spotting Counterfeits

Identity Theft & Recovery Plan

The difference between a minor incident and a long-term headache is speed and process. This section is a practical “what to do next” path you can keep on hand.

If an account is compromised

  1. Secure your email account first (password + MFA).
  2. Change the compromised password (unique, via password manager).
  3. Log out of other sessions/devices.
  4. Review forwarding rules and recovery options.
  5. Check financial accounts and set alerts.

If money is involved

  • Call your bank/card issuer using official numbers.
  • Dispute unauthorized transactions quickly.
  • Document everything: dates, names, case numbers.

Recommended “Recovery Kit”

  • Printed list of key accounts and recovery methods (kept secure)
  • Credit freeze instructions for the major bureaus
  • Backup codes stored safely
  • Trusted family contact plan
Download Recovery Plan Read: Identity Theft Basics

Recommended Tools & Resources

These are categories of tools that help most people. Choose what fits your comfort level and budget. (I do not recommend tools you can’t realistically maintain.)

Password Manager

The single biggest upgrade for most users.

  • What to look for (features checklist)

MFA / Authenticator

Prefer authenticator apps or security keys when available.

  • MFA choices explained

Backups

A simple plan beats a complicated plan you won’t do.

  • The 2-copy method
Recommended Reading Explore All Books

FAQ

Do I really need a password manager?

If you have more than a handful of accounts, yes. Unique passwords are one of the strongest protections you can add. A manager makes “unique and strong” practical—without relying on memory.

Is MFA worth the hassle?

For email and financial accounts, MFA is one of the highest-value steps you can take. It blocks many attacks even when a password is stolen.

What is the single most important account to protect?

Your primary email account. It is used to reset passwords for nearly everything else. Secure it first with a unique password and MFA.

How do I know if a message is a scam?

Look for urgency, unusual payment requests, and links asking you to “verify.” When in doubt, do not click—go to the official website or app yourself.

Want a Clear, Step-by-Step Plan?

If cybersecurity feels overwhelming, start with the basics and build confidence one step at a time. My goal is to make this practical for everyday life—no jargon, no panic.

item.title: Scams & Fraud
item.dc:creator: Grant Ingraham

Avoiding Online Scams: How to Spot Fraud Before It’s Too Late

Online scams are no longer obvious or rare. They are carefully designed to look legitimate, urgent, and personal—targeting everyday users such as parents, seniors, and beginners. This page explains the most common online scams, the warning signs to watch for, and simple decision rules that can protect you before real damage occurs. Key takeaway: Most scams succeed not because of technology, but because they exploit fear, urgency, and trust.

What Are Online Scams? (Quick Answer)

Online scams are fraudulent attempts to trick people into giving away money, personal information, or account access by pretending to be a trusted source. They typically arrive through email, text messages, phone calls, social media, or fake websites.

Why Online Scams Work So Well

Scammers do not rely on advanced hacking. They rely on predictable human reactions.
  • Urgency (“Act now or your account will be closed”)
  • Fear (“Suspicious activity detected”)
  • Authority (“This is your bank / tech support / government agency”)
  • Trust (“I’m a friend who needs help”)
The goal is always the same: push you to act before you stop and think.

Phishing Emails and Text Messages

Phishing uses fake messages that appear to come from legitimate organizations. These messages usually contain links that lead to fake websites designed to steal login credentials. Common phishing themes include:
  • Package delivery problems
  • Password resets
  • Account security alerts
  • Unusual login warnings
Rule: If you did not initiate the contact, do not click the link. Go directly to the organization’s official website instead.

Fake Bank and Financial Alerts

Scammers frequently impersonate banks, credit card companies, and payment services. These messages claim there is a problem with your account that requires immediate action. Banks do not ask for passwords, PINs, or verification codes by email or text. Safe response:
  • Do not reply
  • Do not click links
  • Log in using your bank’s official app or website
  • Call the number on the back of your card if concerned

Tech Support Scams

Tech support scams often begin with alarming pop-ups, emails, or phone calls claiming your computer is infected or compromised. They attempt to convince you to:
  • Call a phone number
  • Install remote access software
  • Pay for unnecessary or fake services
Rule: Legitimate technology companies do not cold-call users about security problems.

Romance and Marketplace Scams

These scams rely on trust rather than fear and often develop slowly.

Romance Scams

  • Emotional connection builds over time
  • Eventually involves money, emergencies, or investments
  • Requests for secrecy are common

Marketplace Scams

  • Requests to move conversations off-platform
  • Fake payments or overpayments
  • Pressure to act quickly
Warning: Requests for gift cards, cryptocurrency, or wire transfers are major red flags.

Common Scam Red Flags

  • Urgency or threats
  • Requests for secrecy
  • Pressure to act immediately
  • Requests for personal or financial information
  • Untraceable payment methods

Simple Decision Rules That Stop Most Scams

  1. Slow down. Scammers rely on speed.
  2. Verify independently. Use known websites or phone numbers.
  3. Never share passwords or codes.
  4. When in doubt, do nothing.
